conclusion: Analyzing the refraction behavior of monochromatic lights at the water-air interface.
Light source S emits two monochromatic lights: A and B, forming two circular illuminated areas on the water surface.
The small inner circle is illuminated by both monochromatic lights A and B (polychromatic).
The larger outer ring is illuminated only by monochromatic light B.
Refractive indices of water for lights A and B are n₁ and n₂ respectively.
Need to find the sine value of the refraction angle of light B at the boundary of the small circle.
Both light rays A and B travel through water and hit the water-air interface, undergoing total internal reflection at a critical angle.
For the small inner circle, both lights A and B can exit the water surface, creating a polychromatic illumination.
For the outer ring, only light B exits, meaning light A has already reached its critical angle.
At the boundary of the small circle, light A reaches its critical angle and the refracted ray travels along the interface.
Using Snell's law for light A: n₁ × sin(θ₁) = 1, therefore sin(θ₁) = 1/n₁.
At the boundary of the small circle, both lights A and B have the same incident angle θ₁.
The incident angle of light B at the boundary is also θ₁ = arcsin(1/n₁).
Using Snell's law for light B: n₂ × sin(θ₁) = sin(θ₂), therefore sin(θ₂) = n₂/n₁.
The sine value of the refraction angle of monochromatic light B at the boundary of the small circle area is n₂/n₁.
